mcqs.question: Which of the following best defines a non-stationary element in data collection as discussed in the lecture?

options.A: An element that maintains constant statistical properties over time.
options.B: An element whose characteristics or state change over time due to environmental or human factors.
options.C: An element that cannot be measured repeatedly with the same instrument.
options.D: An element that is unaffected by sensor drift or external conditions.

mcqs.learning_objective: Differentiate between stationary and non-stationary elements and understand their implications for data collection.

mcqs.question: Which principle from human research ethics emphasizes that individuals should be treated as autonomous agents and given additional protections if autonomy is diminished?
mcqs.learning_objective: Identify the three core ethical principles governing human data collection and apply them appropriately.

essay.prompt: Discuss the key methodological, ethical, and practical considerations in planning and conducting a human-centered data collection study (such as the wearable-sensor gym activity project presented in the lecture). Your answer should: (1) describe how to plan for repeatability, reproducibility, and accuracy; (2) outline how ethical concerns such as informed consent, privacy, and risk-benefit balance should be addressed; and (3) suggest strategies for mitigating technical and human-related data collection problems.

criteria.description: Clearly outlines planning steps including defining goals, procedures, and methodologies.
Describes procedures to ensure data can be replicated under similar conditions.
Explains how others can independently reproduce results from the same dataset.
Mentions calibration, signal verification, and error checking to maintain data accuracy.
Discusses voluntary, informed participation and explains consent procedures for human subjects.
Addresses protection of personal information and limits on data disclosure.
Explains how data will be securely stored and shared only with authorized personnel.
Evaluates participant risks versus benefits and proposes measures to minimize harm.
Includes rationale for selecting a statistically significant sample size.
Explains how variability in human or environmental conditions affects data collection.
Discusses researcher and respondent biases and strategies to reduce them.
Mentions procedures for checking and aligning sensors before and during experiments.
Emphasizes the role of thorough documentation for traceability and quality assurance.
Identifies technical reliability issues and mitigation approaches (e.g., real-time monitoring).
Notes practical difficulties in participant recruitment and compliance.

rubric.grading_notes: Award full marks for structured, well-argued essays demonstrating integration of ethical, methodological, and practical aspects. Partial credit given for coverage of individual points without synthesis.
